threats.mitigation: Avoid using eval() or exec(). Use safer alternatives like ast.literal_eval() or JSON parsing.
Use environment variables or secure credential stores. Never hardcode secrets.

threats.attack_vector: Any origin can access sensitive data
threats.mitigation: Restrict CORS to specific trusted origins. Avoid wildcard (*) in production.

threats.attack_vector: Predictable random values for security-sensitive operations
threats.mitigation: Use cryptographically secure random generators (secrets module, crypto.randomBytes).
Implement proper access controls and role-based authorization.
Avoid using eval() or exec(). Use safer alternatives like ast.literal_eval() or JSON parsing.

threats.attack_vector: Attacker can execute arbitrary system commands
threats.mitigation: Use subprocess with argument lists instead of shell=True. Validate and sanitize all inputs.
Use parameterized queries or ORM methods. Never concatenate user input into SQL.
Use environment variables or secure credential stores. Never hardcode secrets.

threats.attack_vector: Attacker can execute code through crafted serialized objects
threats.mitigation: Use safe deserialization methods like yaml.safe_load(). Validate serialized data.
Sanitize user input. Use framework-provided escaping mechanisms.

threats.attack_vector: Sensitive information leaked in error messages
threats.mitigation: Disable debug mode in production environments.
Implement proper access controls and role-based authorization.
